hypotheses: Demographic factors influence turnover intention among U.S. federal employees.
Workplace satisfaction factors influence turnover intention among U.S. federal employees.
Organizational/relational factors influence turnover intention among U.S. federal employees.
claim.statement: This study develops propositions about why U.S. federal government employees anticipate leaving their jobs along dimensions including demographic, workplace satisfaction, and organizational/relational factors.

data.notes: Data represent full-time, permanent employees on key demographic and geographic indicators.

method.description: The study examines factors predicting voluntary turnover intention among U.S. federal employees using data from the 2006 Federal Human Capital Survey and employs logistic regression models to analyze the data.
steps: Collect data from the 2006 Federal Human Capital Survey.
Formulate hypotheses on turnover intention based on demographic, workplace satisfaction, and organizational/relational factors.
Prepare and preprocess the data for analysis.
Conduct logistic regression analyses to assess the impact of independent variables on turnover intention.
method.independent_variables: Demographic factors, workplace satisfaction factors, organizational/relational factors

results.summary: The findings suggest that overall job satisfaction and age significantly affect turnover intention. Various demographic and organizational/relational factors are also influential.

numerical_results.direction: Mix of positive and negative depending on factors

metadata.original_paper_title: So Hard to Say Goodbye? Turnover Intention among U.S. Federal Employees
